title: How to Prepare a Floor for New Carpet

steps.headline: Move the furniture out of the space to be carpeted.
steps.description: You will want to put it somewhere out of the elements. If you are carpeting a single room, you can put the furniture in another room, but if you are doing an entire house or floor, you may need a garage or storage space. If you are unable to get enough help from friends or neighbors or if you have health problems, you may want to hire furniture movers to take your furniture in and out of the house.

steps.headline: Vacuum the carpet.
steps.description: The act of removing carpet will kick up a lot of dust. If you want to save the carpet for future use, you may choose to rent a carpet cleaner the week before, so that it is clean and dry for storage.

steps.headline: Contact the company that will install your new carpet to find out if carpet removal is included in the price.
steps.description: If it is, you will save time and be assured of a good job done by professionals. If it is not, you may want to inquire about additional time and price for this service.

steps.headline: Hire a contractor if you are removing tile or hardwood flooring in order to install a carpet.
steps.description: These are intensive, specialized processes that should be done with care. It is common for people to cover hardwood floors or concrete floors with carpet.

steps.headline: Remove any doors that open into the room.
steps.description: Take them off at the hinges and store them in another room or in a garage.

steps.headline: Wear appropriate work clothing.
steps.description: Wear shoes, a long-sleeved shirt and long pants. Put on a pair of safety goggles and some gloves. Dangers from carpet removal include injury by nails or tacks, inhalation of dust and contact with mildew or mold. If you have a sensitive respiratory system or you suspect mold, wear a breathing mask.

steps.headline: Open the windows in the room to help clear the room of dust.
Take a pair of strong pliers.
steps.description: Go to the corner of the room and pull up at the edge with the pliers. It is likely that you will be removing the carpet from tack strips that help to pull the carpet and hold it down at the corners.

steps.headline: Go to each of the corners and repeat the process of removing the carpet from the tack strips.
steps.description: This will loosen the carpet and allow you to take off entire lengths of it.

steps.headline: Cut the carpeting into strips with a razor or a specialized carpet cutting tool.
steps.description: This will allow you to roll it up from the end and carry it out in manageable strips. Carpet is extremely heavy, so it is a good idea to remove it in pieces unless you plan on saving the entire piece.

steps.headline: Remove all the carpet before starting to bring up the foam.
steps.description: Use force to pull up as much of the foam as you can. There will be little pieces of foam stuck to staples that you will remove later.

steps.headline: Remove the tack strips.
steps.description: These are very securely attached to the ground in 2 to 4 foot (0.6 to 1.2 m) sections. Place the small pry bar under a corner or edge of the tack strip. Tap the pry bar with the hammer to insert it further underneath. In most cases, the nails will come out of the flooring as you bring up the tack strips. Continue going around the room to remove all the tack strips with the pry bar. If you want to keep the quality of hardwood floor beneath a tack strip, place a small piece of wood beneath the pry bar to avoid dents and scrapes.

steps.headline: If the nails are left in the floor, use pliers or a hammer to remove them once the tack strip is up.
Remove the carpet padding staples.
steps.description: You will need to carry a container to place the staples in, so you do not leave them on the ground. Use a flat head screwdriver or a pair of pliers to yank out the staples 1 by 1. This is a fairly tedious job in large carpeted areas.

steps.headline: Use a flashlight to search the room for any remaining staples or nails.
steps.description: The light should flash on metal surfaces. Sweep the floor to ensure you get up any pieces of metal before  you start your cleaning process.

steps.headline: Go over your floor to see what repairs are needed.
steps.description: Fill in cracks that are 1/8 inch (3 mm) wide or larger. Sand or level discrepancies that are at least 1/32 inch (.8 mm) deep.

steps.headline: Use a latex patching compound and a putty knife to fill in any cracks or depressions in regular wood flooring.
Scuff sand glossy hardwood floors in order to ensure adhesion of carpets.
steps.description: This can be re-sanded and waxed in the future to restore it.

steps.headline: Coat new or sanded wood floors with a primer.
steps.description: This will ensure good bonding with the carpet glue.

steps.headline: Vacuum and dust the wood flooring.
steps.description: Make sure to use very little water when cleaning wooden surfaces. It should be free of grease, oil, wax and dirt to be ready for carpeting.

steps.headline: Patch any holes caused by nails in the concrete.
steps.description: You will need to buy a latex or polymer patching compound from a hardware store. Prime any large areas of patching once they are dry.

steps.headline: Cover the concrete floor with primer, if it is a powdery surface that cannot be cleaned.
steps.description: Consult your carpeting installers to ensure that you choose a primer that is compatible with the adhesive compound they plan to use.

steps.headline: Clean the surface of the concrete.
steps.description: Apply a solution of tri-sodium phosphate to ensure a completely clean surface. Rinse well and open windows so the surface dries completely.

text: Clearing\/Cleaning the Carpet Move the furniture out of the space to be carpeted. You will want to put it somewhere out of the elements. If you are carpeting a single room, you can put the furniture in another room, but if you are doing an entire house or floor, you may need a garage or storage space. If you are unable to get enough help from friends or neighbors or if you have health problems, you may want to hire furniture movers to take your furniture in and out of the house. Vacuum the carpet. The act of removing carpet will kick up a lot of dust. If you want to save the carpet for future use, you may choose to rent a carpet cleaner the week before, so that it is clean and dry for storage. Contact the company that will install your new carpet to find out if carpet removal is included in the price. If it is, you will save time and be assured of a good job done by professionals. If it is not, you may want to inquire about additional time and price for this service. Hire a contractor if you are removing tile or hardwood flooring in order to install a carpet. These are intensive, specialized processes that should be done with care. It is common for people to cover hardwood floors or concrete floors with carpet. Remove any doors that open into the room. Take them off at the hinges and store them in another room or in a garage. Removing Carpeting Wear appropriate work clothing. Wear shoes, a long-sleeved shirt and long pants. Put on a pair of safety goggles and some gloves. Dangers from carpet removal include injury by nails or tacks, inhalation of dust and contact with mildew or mold. If you have a sensitive respiratory system or you suspect mold, wear a breathing mask. Open the windows in the room to help clear the room of dust.  Take a pair of strong pliers. Go to the corner of the room and pull up at the edge with the pliers. It is likely that you will be removing the carpet from tack strips that help to pull the carpet and hold it down at the corners. Go to each of the corners and repeat the process of removing the carpet from the tack strips. This will loosen the carpet and allow you to take off entire lengths of it. Cut the carpeting into strips with a razor or a specialized carpet cutting tool. This will allow you to roll it up from the end and carry it out in manageable strips. Carpet is extremely heavy, so it is a good idea to remove it in pieces unless you plan on saving the entire piece. Remove all the carpet before starting to bring up the foam. Use force to pull up as much of the foam as you can. There will be little pieces of foam stuck to staples that you will remove later. Remove the tack strips. These are very securely attached to the ground in 2 to 4 foot (0.6 to 1.2 m) sections. Place the small pry bar under a corner or edge of the tack strip. Tap the pry bar with the hammer to insert it further underneath. In most cases, the nails will come out of the flooring as you bring up the tack strips. Continue going around the room to remove all the tack strips with the pry bar. If you want to keep the quality of hardwood floor beneath a tack strip, place a small piece of wood beneath the pry bar to avoid dents and scrapes. If the nails are left in the floor, use pliers or a hammer to remove them once the tack strip is up.  Remove the carpet padding staples. You will need to carry a container to place the staples in, so you do not leave them on the ground. Use a flat head screwdriver or a pair of pliers to yank out the staples 1 by 1. This is a fairly tedious job in large carpeted areas. Use a flashlight to search the room for any remaining staples or nails. The light should flash on metal surfaces. Sweep the floor to ensure you get up any pieces of metal before  you start your cleaning process. Preparing Wood Flooring Go over your floor to see what repairs are needed. Fill in cracks that are 1/8 inch (3 mm) wide or larger. Sand or level discrepancies that are at least 1/32 inch (.8 mm) deep. Use a latex patching compound and a putty knife to fill in any cracks or depressions in regular wood flooring.  Scuff sand glossy hardwood floors in order to ensure adhesion of carpets. This can be re-sanded and waxed in the future to restore it. Coat new or sanded wood floors with a primer. This will ensure good bonding with the carpet glue. Vacuum and dust the wood flooring. Make sure to use very little water when cleaning wooden surfaces. It should be free of grease, oil, wax and dirt to be ready for carpeting. Preparing Concrete Flooring Patch any holes caused by nails in the concrete. You will need to buy a latex or polymer patching compound from a hardware store. Prime any large areas of patching once they are dry. Cover the concrete floor with primer, if it is a powdery surface that cannot be cleaned. Consult your carpeting installers to ensure that you choose a primer that is compatible with the adhesive compound they plan to use. Clean the surface of the concrete. Apply a solution of tri-sodium phosphate to ensure a completely clean surface. Rinse well and open windows so the surface dries completely.
sentences: Clearing\/Cleaning the Carpet Move the furniture out of the space to be carpeted.
You will want to put it somewhere out of the elements.
If you are carpeting a single room, you can put the furniture in another room, but if you are doing an entire house or floor, you may need a garage or storage space.
If you are unable to get enough help from friends or neighbors or if you have health problems, you may want to hire furniture movers to take your furniture in and out of the house.
Vacuum the carpet.
The act of removing carpet will kick up a lot of dust.
If you want to save the carpet for future use, you may choose to rent a carpet cleaner the week before, so that it is clean and dry for storage.
Contact the company that will install your new carpet to find out if carpet removal is included in the price.
If it is, you will save time and be assured of a good job done by professionals.
If it is not, you may want to inquire about additional time and price for this service.
Hire a contractor if you are removing tile or hardwood flooring in order to install a carpet.
These are intensive, specialized processes that should be done with care.
It is common for people to cover hardwood floors or concrete floors with carpet.
Remove any doors that open into the room.
Take them off at the hinges and store them in another room or in a garage.
Removing Carpeting Wear appropriate work clothing.
Wear shoes, a long-sleeved shirt and long pants.
Put on a pair of safety goggles and some gloves.
Dangers from carpet removal include injury by nails or tacks, inhalation of dust and contact with mildew or mold.
If you have a sensitive respiratory system or you suspect mold, wear a breathing mask.
Open the windows in the room to help clear the room of dust.
Take a pair of strong pliers.
Go to the corner of the room and pull up at the edge with the pliers.
It is likely that you will be removing the carpet from tack strips that help to pull the carpet and hold it down at the corners.
Go to each of the corners and repeat the process of removing the carpet from the tack strips.
This will loosen the carpet and allow you to take off entire lengths of it.
Cut the carpeting into strips with a razor or a specialized carpet cutting tool.
This will allow you to roll it up from the end and carry it out in manageable strips.
Carpet is extremely heavy, so it is a good idea to remove it in pieces unless you plan on saving the entire piece.
Remove all the carpet before starting to bring up the foam.
Use force to pull up as much of the foam as you can.
There will be little pieces of foam stuck to staples that you will remove later.
Remove the tack strips.
These are very securely attached to the ground in 2 to 4 foot (0.6 to 1.2 m) sections.
Place the small pry bar under a corner or edge of the tack strip.
Tap the pry bar with the hammer to insert it further underneath.
In most cases, the nails will come out of the flooring as you bring up the tack strips.
Continue going around the room to remove all the tack strips with the pry bar.
If you want to keep the quality of hardwood floor beneath a tack strip, place a small piece of wood beneath the pry bar to avoid dents and scrapes.
If the nails are left in the floor, use pliers or a hammer to remove them once the tack strip is up.
Remove the carpet padding staples.
You will need to carry a container to place the staples in, so you do not leave them on the ground.
Use a flat head screwdriver or a pair of pliers to yank out the staples 1 by 1.
This is a fairly tedious job in large carpeted areas.
Use a flashlight to search the room for any remaining staples or nails.
The light should flash on metal surfaces.
Sweep the floor to ensure you get up any pieces of metal before  you start your cleaning process.
Preparing Wood Flooring Go over your floor to see what repairs are needed.
Fill in cracks that are 1/8 inch (3 mm) wide or larger.
Sand or level discrepancies that are at least 1/32 inch (.8 mm) deep.
Use a latex patching compound and a putty knife to fill in any cracks or depressions in regular wood flooring.
Scuff sand glossy hardwood floors in order to ensure adhesion of carpets.
This can be re-sanded and waxed in the future to restore it.
Coat new or sanded wood floors with a primer.
This will ensure good bonding with the carpet glue.
Vacuum and dust the wood flooring.
Make sure to use very little water when cleaning wooden surfaces.
It should be free of grease, oil, wax and dirt to be ready for carpeting.
Preparing Concrete Flooring Patch any holes caused by nails in the concrete.
You will need to buy a latex or polymer patching compound from a hardware store.
Prime any large areas of patching once they are dry.
Cover the concrete floor with primer, if it is a powdery surface that cannot be cleaned.
Consult your carpeting installers to ensure that you choose a primer that is compatible with the adhesive compound they plan to use.
Clean the surface of the concrete.
Apply a solution of tri-sodium phosphate to ensure a completely clean surface.
Rinse well and open windows so the surface dries completely.
